title: heavy condensed face, very square, rounded corners
content:
Sorry my first post is this kinda post.

I don’t need an ID as much as I need help tracking down  
something like this quick sample I made that’s similar  
to what I’m looking for.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071216030333im_/http:/typophile.com/files/read_6738.jpg)

I saw a posting on another site a few weeks ago that  
announced a new family had been released that had similar  
traits to this but I can’t remember where/who it was.

Futura Display in the old Letraset catalog has some of  
the features I want (very upright, rounded corners) but  
the M and N are lowercase and look dated, and I really  
need something contemporary looking

thanks in advance.

 [‹ (x) 50 JPG catalogue cover - Apex Sans, Arnhem {Paolo Mazzetti, Yves}](http://web.archive.org/web/20071216030333/http:/typophile.com/node/38962 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) "Mère & monde" website font - Optima {Jan E} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071216030333/http:/typophile.com/node/39032 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Nolen

comments.content:
Nolan~

You might try my font “Laconic”.

It’s a free download at:  
 [http://www.woodardworks.com/type13.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20071216030333/http:/www.woodardworks.com/type13.html "http://www.woodardworks.com/type13.html")

If you using an OpenType app, there is a stylistic alt “R” that is more like your original.

R\V

Not quite what I had in mind for this project, but thanks.

Another point of reference would be the David Boring  
title that Dan Clowes drew. Normally I would just hand  
render what I need, but this needs to clean and crisp.
